Gentleman usher
Gentleman usher.

div.p: THE GENTLEMAN USHER. By GEORGE CHAPMAN.
AT LONDON Printed by V. S. for Thomas Thorppe. 1606.

sp.speaker: Strozza.
sp.p: HAste nephew, what, a sluggard? Fie for shame, Shal he that was our morning Cock, turn Owle, And locke out day light from his drowsie eies?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Pray pardon mee for once, lord vnkle, for Ile bee sworne, I had such a dreame this morning: me thought one came with a commission to take a Sorrell curtoll, that was stolne from him, wheresoeuer hee could find him. And because I feared he would lay claime to my sorrell curtoll in my stable I ran to the Smith to haue him set on his mane againe, and his taile presently, that the Commission-man might not thinke him a curtoll. And when the Smith would not doe it, I fell a beating of him, so that I could not wake for my life til I was reuenged on him.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: This is your old valure nephew, that will fight sleeping as well as waking.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Slud Aunt, what if my dreame had beene true (as it might haue beene for any thing I knew) there's neuer a smith in Italie, shall make an Asse of me in my sleepe, if I can chuse.

lg.l: Well said, my furious nephew: but I see
You quite forget that we must rowse to day
The sharp-tuskt Bore: and blaze our huntsmanship before the duke.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p:
Forget Lord vncle? I hope not; you thinke belike
my wittes are as brittle as a Beetle, or as skittish as your Barbarie Mare: one cannot crie wehie, but straight shee cries tihi.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Well ghest coosen Hysteron Proteron.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But which way will the dukes grace hunt to day?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Toward Count Lassos house his Grace will hunt, Where he will visit his late honourd mistresse.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Who Ladie Margaret, that deare yong dame? Will his antiquitie, neuer leane his iniquitie?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Why how now nephew? turnd Parnassus lately?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nassus? I know not: but I would I had all the dukes liuing for her sake, Ide make him a poore duke ifaith.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: No doubt of that, if thou hadst all his liuing.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I would not stand dreaming of the matter as I do now.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Why how doe you dreame nephew?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Mary all last night me thought I was tying her shoo-string.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: What all night tying her shoostring?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I that I was, and yet I tied it not neither; for as I was tying it, the string broke me thought, and then me thought, hauing but one poynt at my hose, me thought, I gaue her that to tie her shoo with all.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: A poynt of much kindnesse I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Whervpon, in the verie nicke me thought the Count came rushing in, and I ranne rushing out, with my heeles about my hose for haste.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: So, will you leaue your dreaming, and dispatch?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Mum, not a worde more, Ile goe before, and ouertake you presently.

lg.l: My Lord I fancie not these hunting sports,
When the bold game you follow turnes againe,
And stares you in the face: let me behold
A cast of Faulcons on their merry wings,
Daring the stooped prey, that shifting flies:
Or let me view the fearefull Hare or Hinde,
Tosst like a musicke point with harmonie
Of well mouthed hounds. This is a sport for Princes,
The other rude Boares yeeld fit game for Boores.
Thy timorous spirit blinds thy iudgement, wife,
Those are most royall sports that most approue
The huntsmans prowesse, and his hardie minde.
My Lord, I know too well your vertuous spirit,
Take heede for Gods loue if you rowse the Bore,
You come not neere him, but discharge aloofe
Your wounding Pistoll, or well aymed Dart.
I Mary wife this counsaile rightly flowes
Out of thy bosome, pray thee take lesse care,
Let Ladies at their tables iudge of Bores,
Lords in the field: And so farewell sweete loue;
Faile not to meete me at Earle Lassos house.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Pray pardon me for that: you know I loue not These solemne meetings.

lg.l: You must needes, for once
Constraine your disposition; and indeede
I would acquaint you more with Ladie Margaret,
For speciall reason.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Very good, my Lord. Then I must needes go fit me for that presence.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I pray thee doe, farewell.
Here comes my friend.

lg.l: Good day my Lord; why does your grace confront
So cleare a morning with so clowdie lookes?
Ask'st thou my griefes, that knowst my desprate loue
Curbd by my fathers sterne realitie:
Must not I mourne that know not whether yet
I shall enioy a stepdame or a wife?
A wife prince, neuer doubt it; your deserts
And youthfull graces haue engag'd so farre,
The beauteous Margaret, that she is your owne.
O but the eie of watchfull iealousie
Robs my desires of meanest inioy her fauour.
Despaire not: there are meanes enow for you,
Suborne some seruant of some good respect,
Thats neere your choice, who though she needs no wooing,
May yet imagine you are to begin,
Your strange yong loue sute, and so speake for you,
Beare your kind letters, and get safe accesse.
All which when he shall do; you neede not feare
His trustie secrecie, because he dares not
Reueale escapes, where of himselfe is Author,
Whom you may best attempt, she must reueale;
For if she loues you, she already knowes,
And in an instant can resolue you that.
And so she will, I doubt not: would to heauen
I had fit time, euen now to know her minde:
This counsaile feedes my heart with much sweet hope.
Pursue it then; t'will not be hard t'effect:
The Duke haz none for him, but Medice
That fustian Lord, who in his buckram face,
Bewraies, in my conceit, a map of basenesse.
I, theres a parcell of vnconstrued stuffe,
That vnknowne Minion raisde to honours height,
Without the helpe of Vertue, or of Art,
Or (to say true) nay of honest part:
O how she shames my father! he goes like
A Princes foote-man, in old fashioned silkes,
And most times, in his hose and dublet onely,
So miserable, that his owne few men
Doe beg by vertue of his liuerie;
For he giues none for any seruice done him,
Or any honour, any least reward.
Tis pittie such should liue about a Prince:
I would haue such a noble counterfet, nailde
Vpon the Pillory, and after, whipt
For his adultery with nobilitie,
Faith I would faine disgrace him by all meanes,
As enemy to his base-bred ignorance,
That being a great Lord, cannot write nor reade.
For that, weelle follow the blinde side of him,
And make it sometimes subiect of our mirth.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: See, what newes with your Nephew Pogio?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: None good I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Where should I finde my Lord Vnckle?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Whats the huge haste with you?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: O ho, you will hunt to day.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I hope I will.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But you may hap to hop without your hope: for the truth is, Kilbucke is runne mad.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Whats this?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nay, t'is true sir: and Kilbucke being runne mad, bit Ringwood so by the left buttocke, you might haue turnd your nose in it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Out Asse.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: By heauen you might my Lord: d'ee thinke I he?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Zwoundes, might I? lets blanket him my Lord: a blanket heere.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord Vincentio, by this rush I tell you for good will: and Venus your brache there, runnes so prowd, that your Hunts man cannot take her downe for his life.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Take her vp foole, thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Why sir, he would soone take her down and he could take her vp I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: Well said, ham mer, hammer.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Nay, good now lets alone, and theres your horse, Gray Strozza too haz the staggers, and haz strooke bay. Bettrice, your Barbary mare so, that shee goes halting a this fashion, most filthily.

sp.speaker: Stro.

lg.l: What poison blisters thy vnhappy tongue
Euermore braying forth vnhappy newes,
Our hunting sport is at the best my Lord:
How shall I satisfie the Duke your father,
Defrauding him of his expected sport?
See, see, he comes.

sp.stage: Enter Alphonso, Medice, Sarpego, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Is this the copie of the speech you wrote, Signieur Sarpego?

lg.l: It is a blaze of wit pocticall,
Reade it, braue Duke, with eyes pathetical.
We will peruse it strait: well met Vincentio,
And good Lord Strozza, we commend you both
For your attendance: but you must conceiue,
Tis no true hunting we intend to day,
But an inducement to a certaine shew,
Wherewith we will present our beateous loue,
And therein we bespeake your company.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: We both are ready to attend your Highnesse.

lg.l: See then, heere is a Poeme that requires
Your worthy censures; offerd if it like
To furnish our intended amorous shew:
Reade it Uincentio.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Pardon me my Lord, Lord Medices reading, will expresse it better,

lg.l: My patience can digest your scoffes my Lord.
I care not to proclaime it to the world:
I can nor write, nor reade; and what of that?
I can both see and heare, as well as you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Still are your wits at warre: heere, read this poeme.

lg.l: The red fac'd Sunne hath firkt the flundering shades,
And cast bright ammell on Auroraes brow.
High words and strange:
Reade on Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: The busky groues that gag-tooth'd boares do shrowd With cringle crangle hornes do ring alowd.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord, I haue a speech heere worth ten of this, and yet Ile mend it too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: How likes Vincentio?

lg.l: It is strangely good,
No inkehorne euer did bring forth the like,
Could these braue prancing words with Actions spurre,
Be ridden throughly, and managed right,
T'would fright the audience, and perhaps delight.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.p: Doubt you of action sir?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I, for such stuffe.

lg.l: Then know my Lord, I can both act and teach
To any words; when I in Padua schoolde it,
I plaid in one of Plautus Comedies,
Namely, Curculto, where his part I acted,
Proiecting from the poore summe of foure lines,
Forty faire actions.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Lets see that I pray.

lg.l: Your Highnesse shall commaund,
But pardon me, if in my actions heate
Entering in post post haste I chaunce to take vp
Some of your honord heels;

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Y'ad best leaue out that action for a thing that I know sir.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.p: Then shal you see what I can do without it.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: See see, he hath his furniture and all.

lg.l: You must imagine, Lords, I bring good newes,
Whereof being princely prowd I scowre the streete
And ouer-tumble euery man I meete.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Beshrew my heart if he take vp my heeles.

lg.l: Date viam mihi Noti, atque Ignoti.
Dum ego, h√Æc, officium meum facio.
Fugite omnes atque abite, & de via secedite, ne quem
in cursu; aut capite, aut cubito, aut pectore offendam, aut genu.
Thankes good Seigneur Sarpego.
How like you Lords, this stirring action?
In a cold morning it were good my Lord.
But something harshe vpon repletion.
Sir I haue ventred, being enioynde to eate
Three schollers commons, and yet drewe it neate.

sp.speaker: Pogio.
sp.p: Come sir, you meddle in too many matters; let vs I pray tend on our owne shew at my lord Lassos.

lg.l: Doing obeisance then to euery lord
I now consorte you sir euen toto corde.
My lord, away with these scholastique wits,
Lay the inuention of your speech on me,
And the performance too; ile play my parte,
that you shall say, Nature yeelds more then Art.
Bee't so resolu'd; vnartificiall truth
An vnfaind passion can descipher best.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But t'wil be hard my lord, for one vnlearnd.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Vnlearnd? I cry you mercie sir; vnlearnd?

lg.l: I meane, vntaught my lord, to make a speech,
As a pretended Actor, without close,
More gratious then your doublet and your hose.
What, think you sonne we meane t'expresse a speech
Of speciall weight without a like attire?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Excuse me then my lord; so stands it well.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Haz brought them rarely in, to pageant him.

lg.l: What; thinke you lord; we thinke not of attire?
Can we not make vs ready at this age?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Alas my lord, your wit must pardon his.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I hope it will, his wit is pittyfull.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I pray stand by my Lord; y'are troublesome.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: To none but you; am I to you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Not vnto mee.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Why then you wrong me Strozza.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Nay, fall not out my Lords.

lg.l: May I not know
What your speech is my Liege?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: None but my selfe, and the Lord Medice.

lg.l: No, pray my Lord
Let none partake with vs.
No be assur'd,
But for another cause; a word Lord Strozza,
I tell you true, I feare Lord Medice
Will scarce discharge the speach effectually:
As we goe therefore, ile explaine to you
My whole intent; that you may second him
If neede and his debilitie require.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Thanks for this grace my Liege.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: My Lord; your sonne.

lg.l: Why how now sonne? forbeare; yet tis no matter
Wee talke of other businesse Medice
And come, we will prepare vs to our shew.

sp.speaker: Stro. Vin.
sp.p: Which as we can, weele cast to ouerthrow.
sp.stage: Enter Lasso, Corteza, Margaret, Bassiolo, Sarpego, two Pages, Bassiolo bare before.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Stand by there, make place.

lg.l: Saie now Bassiolo; you on whom relies
The generall disposition of my house,
In this our preparation, for the Duke
Are all our officers at large instructed,
For fit discharge of their peculiar places?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: At large my lord instructed.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Are all our chambers hung? Thinke you our house amplie capacious to lodge all the traine?

lg.l: Amply capacious: I am passing glad.
And now then to our mirth and musicall shew,
Which after supper we intend t'indure,
Welcomes cheefe dainties: for choice cates at home,
Euer attend on Princes; mirth abroad,
Are all parts perfect.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.p: One I know there is.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: And that is yours.

lg.l: Well guest in earnest Lord,
I neede not erubescere, to take
So much vpon me: That my backe will beare.
Nay, he will be perfection it selfe,
For wording well, and dexterous action too.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: And will these waggish pages, hit their songs?

sp.speaker: 2 Pag.
sp.p: Remi fa solla?

lg.l: O they are practising; good boyes, well done;
But where is Pogio? there y'are ouershot.
To lay a capitall part vpon his braine,
Whose absence tells me plainely hee'le neglect him.
O no my Lord, he dreames of nothing else,
And giues it out in wagers, hee'le excell;
And see, (I told your Lo:) he is come.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: How now my Lord, haue you borrowed a Snite for me: Seigneur Bassiolo, can all say, are all things ready? the Duke is hard by, and little thinks that Ile be an Actor ifaith, I keepe all close my Lord.

lg.l: O, tis well done, call all the Ladies in,
Sister and daughter, come, for Gods sake come,
Prepare your courtliest carriage for the Duke.
Corte And Neece, in any case remember this,
Praise the old man, and when you see him first,
Looke me on none but him, smiling and louingly:
And then, when he comes neere, make beisance low,
With both your hands thus mouing, which not onely
Is as t'were courtly, and most comely too,
But speakes (as who should say) come hither Duke;
And yet saies nothing, but you may denie.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Well taught sister.

lg.l: I, and to much end:
I am exceeding fond to humour him.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Harke, does he come with musicke? what, and bound?
An amorous deuice: daughter, obserue.
sp.stage: Enter Enchanter, with spirits singing; after them; Medice, like Syluanus, next the Duke bound, Vincentio, Strozza, with other.

lg.l: Now lets gull Medice, I doe not doubt,
But this attire put on, will put him out.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Weele doe our best to that end, therefore marke.

lg.l: Lady, or Princesse, both your choice commands.
These spirits and I, all seruants of your beautie,
Present this royall captiue to your mercie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Captiue to mee a subiect.

lg.l: I, faire Nimph;
And how the worthy mystery befell
Syluanus heere, this woodden god can tell.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Now is the time man, speake.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Peace Vincentio.

lg.l: Swonds my Lord,
Shall I stand by and suffer him to shame you?
My Lord Medice?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Will you not speake my Lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: How can I?

lg.l: But you must speake in earnest:
Would not your Highnesse haue him speake my Lord?
Yes, and I will speake, and perhaps speake so,
As you shall neuer mend: I can I know.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Doe then my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Medice, forth.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Goddesse, faire goddesse, for no lesse, no lesse.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No. lesse, no lesse? no more, no more: speake you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Swounds they haue put me out.

lg.l: Laugh your faire goddesse,
This nobleman disdaines to be your foole.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Vincentio, peace.

lg.l: Swounds my Lord, it is as good a shew:
Pray speake Lord Strozza.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.p: Honourable dame.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Take heede you be not out I pray my Lord.

lg.l: I pray forbeare my Lord Vincentio:
How this destressed Prince came thus inthralde,
I must relate with words of height and wonder:
His Grace this morning visiting the woods,
And straying farre, to finde game for the Chase,
At last, out of a mirtle groue he rowsde
A vast and dreadfull Boare, so sterne and fierce,
As if the Feend fell Crueltie her selfe
Had come to fright the woods in that strange shape.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Excellent good.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Too good a plague on him.

lg.l: The princely Sauage being thus on foote,
Tearing the earth vp with his thundering hoofe,
And with the'nragde Aetna of his breath.
Firing the ayre, and scorching all the woods,
Horror held all vs Huntsmen from pursuit,
Onely the Duke incenst with our cold feare,
Incouragde like a second Hercules.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Zwounds, too good man.

lg.l: Pray thee let me alone:
And like the English signe of great Saint George.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Plague of that Simile.

lg.l: Gaue valorous example, and like fire,
Hunted the monster close, and chargde so fierce,
That he inforc'd him (as our sence conceiu'd)
To leape for soile into a cristall spring,
Where on the suddaine strangely vanishing,
Nimph-like for him, out of the waues arose
Your sacred figure like Diana armde,
And (as in purpose of the beasts reuenge)
Dischargde an arrow through his Highnesse breast,
Whence yet no wound or any blood appearde:
With which, the angry shadow left the light:
And this Enchanter with his power of spirits,
Brake from a caue, scattering enchanted sounds,
That strooke vs sencelesse, while in these strange bands,
These cruell spirits thus inchainde his armes,
And led him captiue to your heauenly eyes,
Th'intent whereof on their report relies.
Bright Nimph, that Boare figur'd your crueltie,
Chared by loue, defended by your beautie.
This amorous Huntsman heere, we thus inthral'd,
As the attendants on your Graces charmes,
And brought him hither by your bounteous hands.
To be releast, or liue in endlesse bands.
Daughter, release the Duke: alas my Liege.
What meant your Highnesse to indure this wrong?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Enlarge him Neece, come dame, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What Madam, shall I arrogate so much?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: His Highnesse pleasure is to grace you so.

lg.l: Performe it then sweete loue, it is a deede
Worthy the office of your honor'd hand.
Too worthie I confesse my Lord for me,
If it were serious: but it is in sport,
And women are fit Actors for such pageants.
Thanks gracious loue; why made you strange of this?
I rest no lesse your captiue then before,
For me vntying, you haue tied me more.
Thanks Strozza for your speech, no thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: No, thanke your sonne my Lord.

lg.l: T'was very well,
Exceeding well performed on euery part,
How say you Bassiolo?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Rare I protest my Lord.

lg.l: O, my Lord Medice became it rarely,
Me thought I likde his manlie being out;
It becomes Noblemen to doe nothing well.
Now then wil't please your Grace to grace our house,
And still vouchsafe our seruice further honour.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Leade vs my Lord, we will your daughter leade.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You do not leade, but drag her leaden steps.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: How did you like my speech?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O fie vpon't, your Rhetoricke was too fine.

lg.l: Nothing at all:
I hope saint Georges signe was grosse enough:
But (to be serious) as these warnings passe,
Watch you your father, Ile watch Medice,
That in your loue-suit, we may shun suspect:
To which end, with your next occasion, vrge
Your loue to name the person she will choose,
By whose meanes you may safely write or meete.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Thats our cheefe businesse: and see, heere she comes.

lg.l: My Lord, I onely come to say, y'are welcome,
And so must say, farewell.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: One word I pray.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whats that?

lg.l: You needes must presently deuise,
What person trusted chiefely with your guard,
You thinke is aptest for me to corrupt,
In making him a meane for our safe meeting?
My fathers Vsher, none so fit,
If you can worke him well: and so farewell,
With thanks my good Lord Strozza for your speech.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I thanke you for your patience, mocking Lady.

lg.l: O what a fellow haz she pickt vs out?
One that I would haue choosde past all the rest,
For his close stockings onely.
And why not?
For the most constant fashion of his hat?
Nay then, if nothing must be left vnspoke,
For his strict forme, thus still to weare his cloke.
Well sir, he is your owne, I make no doubt:
For to these outward figures of his minde,
He hath two inward swallowing properties
Of any gudgeons; seruile Auarice,
And ouerweening thought of his owne worth,
Ready to snatch at euery shade of glory:
And therefore, till you can directlie boord him,
Waft him aloofe with hats, and other fauours,
Still as you meete him.
Well, let me alone,
He that is one mans slaue, is free from none.

div.head: ACTVS SECVNDVS
SCAENA PRIMA.
div.stage: Enter Medice, Corteza a Page with a cuppe of Sacke, Strozza following close.

lg.l: Come Lady, sit you heere: Page, fill some Sacke,
I am to worke vpon this aged Dame,
To gleane from her, if there be any cause
(In louing others) of her Neeces coines
To the most gratious loue suite of the Duke:
Heere noble Lady, this is healthfull drinke
After our supper.
O, tis that my Lorde,
That of all drinkes keeps life and soule in me.
Heere, fill it Page, for this my worthy loue:
O how I could imbrace this good olde widdow.
Now lord, when you do thus, you make me thinke
Of my sweete husband; for he was as like you;
Eene the same words, and fashion: the same eies,
Manly, and cholerike, eene as you are iust,
And eene as kinde as you for all the world.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O my sweete widdow, thou dost make me prowd.

sp.speaker: Cort:
sp.p: Nay, I am too old for you.

lg.l: Too old, thats nothing,
Come pledge me wench, for I am drie againe,
And strait will charge your widdowhood fresh ifaith:
Why thats well done.

sp.speaker: Cort:
sp.p: Now fie on't, heere's a draught.

lg.l: O, it will warme your blood: if you should sip,
Twould make you heart burnd.
Faith and so they say:
Yet I must tell you, since I plide this geere,
I haue beene hanted with a horson paine heere,
And euery moone almost with a shrewd feuer,
And yet I cannot leaue it: for thanke God,
I neuer was more sound of winde and limbe.
Looke you, I warrant you I haue a leg,
Holds out as hansomly.
Beshrew my life,
But tis a legge indeed, a goodly limbe.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: This is most excellent.

lg.l: O that your Neece
Were of as milde a spirit as your selfe.
Alas Lord Medice, would you haue a girle.
As well seene in behauiour as I?
Ah shees a fond yong thing, and growne so prowde,
The wind must blow at west stil, or sheele be angry.
Masse so me thinke; how coy shees to the duke?
I lay my life she haz some yonger loue.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: Faith like enough.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Gods me, who should it bee?

lg.l: If it be any; Page, a little Sacke.
If it be any: harke now; if it be,
I know not, by this Sacke, but if it be,
Marke what I say, my Lord; I drinke tee first.
Well said good widdow, much good do thy heart,
So; now what if it be?
Well, if it be;
To come to that I said, for so I said,
If it be any, Tis the Shrewde yong Prince,
For eies can speake, and eies can vnderstand,
And I haue markt her eies; yet by this cup,
Which I will onely kisse.
O noble Crone,
Now such a huddle and kettle neuer was.
I neuer yet haue seene; not yet I say,
But I will marke her after for your sake.
And doe I pray; for it is passing like;
And there is Strozza, a slie Counsailor
To the yong boy: O I would giue a limbe,
To haue their knauerie limm'd and painted out.
They stand vpon their wits and paper learning:
Giue me a fellow with a naturall wit,
That can make wit of no wit; and wade through
Great things with nothing, when their wits sticke fast,
O they be scuruie Lords.
Faith so they be,
Your Lordship still is of my mind in all,
And eene so was my husband.
Gods my life,
Strozza hath Euesdropt here, and ouer-heard vs.
They haue descried me; what Lord Medice
Courting the lustie widow?
I, and why not?
Perhaps one does as much for you at home.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: What, cholericke man? and toward wedlocke too?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: And if he be my Lord; he may do woorse.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: If he be not; madame he may do better.
sp.stage: Enter Bassiolo with seruants with Rushes, and a Carpet.

lg.l: My Lords, and Madame, the Dukes grace intreates you
T'attend his new-made Dutchesse for this night,
Into his presence.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: We are readie sir.

lg.l: Come strew this roome afresh; spread here this carpet,
Nay quickly man, I pray thee; this way foole,
Lay me it smoothe, and Euen; looke if he will;
This way a little more: a little there.
Hast thou no forecast? slood me thinks a man
Should not of meere necessitie be an Asse.
Looke how he strowes here too: Come sir Giles Goosecap,
I must do all my selfe, lay me vm thus:
In fine smoothe threaues, looke you sir, thus in threaues.
Perhaps some tender Ladie will squat here,
And if some standing Rush should chance to pricke her,
Shee'd squeak & spoile the songs that must be sung.
See where he is; now to him, and prepare
Your familiaritie.
Saue you master Bassiolo,
I pray a word sir; but I feare I let you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: No my good Lord, no let.

lg.l: I thanke you sir.
Nay pray be couerd; O I crie you mercie,
You must be bare.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Euer to you my Lord,

lg.l: Nay, not to me sir,
But to the faire right of your worshipfull place.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: A shame of both your worships.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: What means your Lordship?

lg.l: Onely to doe you right sir, and my selfe ease.
And what sir, will there be some shew to night?
A slender presentation of some musick
And some thing else my Lord.
T'is passing good sir,
Ile not be ouer bold t'aske the particulars.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Yes, if your Lordship please.

lg.l: O no good sir,
But I did wonder much; for as me thought
I saw your hands at work.
Or else my Lord
Our busines would be but badly done.
How vertuous is a worthy mans example?
Who is this throne for pray?
For my Lords daughter,
Whom the duke makes to represent his dutches.
T'will be exceeding fit; and all this roome
Is passing wel preparde; a man would sweare,
That all presentments in it would be rare.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, see if thou canst lay vm thus in threaues.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: In threaues dee call it?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I my Lord in threaues.

lg.l: A pretty terme:
Well sir I thanke you highly for this kindnesse,
And pray you alwayes make as bold with me
For kindnesse more then this, if more may bee.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O my Lord this is nothing.

lg.l: Sir, tis much.
And now ile leaue you sir; I know y'are busie.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Faith sir alittle.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I commend me tee Sir.

lg.l: A courteous prince beleeue it; I am sory
I was no bolder with him; what a phrase
He vsde at parting! I commend me tee.
Ile h'ate yfaith;
Good master Vsher, will you dictate to me,
Which is the part precedent of this night-cap,
And which posterior? I do ignorare
How I should weare it.
Why sir; this I take it
Is the precedent part; I, so it is.

sp.speaker: Sarp.
sp.p: And is all well sir thinke you?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Passing well.

lg.l: Why sir come on; the Vsher shal be iudge:
See master Vsher: this same Fungus here,
Your Lords retainer, whom I hope you rule,
Would weare this better Ierkin for the Rush-man,
When I doe play the Broome-man; and speake first.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Why sir, I borrowed it, and I will weare it.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: What sir, in spite of your Lords gentleman, Vsher:

lg.l: No spite sir, but you haue changde twice already,
And now woulde ha't againe.
Why thats all one sir,
Gentillitie must be fantasticall.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I pray thee Fungus let master Pogio weare it.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: And what shall I weare then?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Why here is one, that was a Rush-mans Ierkin, and I pray, wer't not absurd then; a Broome-man should weare it?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Foe, theres a reason, I will keepe it sir.

lg.l: Will sir; then do your office maister Vsher,
Make him put off his Ierkin; you may plucke
His coate ouer his cares, much more his Ierkin.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Fungus y'ad best be rulde.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Best sir! I care not.

lg.l: No sir? I hope you are my Lords retainer.
I neede not care a pudding for your Lord:
But spare not, keepe it, for perhaps Ile play
My part as well in this, as you in that,

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well said, master Pogio; my Lord shall know it.
sp.stage: Enter Corteza, with the Broom-wench, & Rush-wench in their petticotes, clokes ouer them, with hats ouer their head-tyres.

lg.l: Looke master Vsher, are these wags wel drest?
I haue beene so in labour with-vm truly.

sp.speaker: Bass.

lg.l: Y'aue had a verie good deliuerance, Ladie:
How I did take her at her labour there,
I vse to gird these Ladies so sometimes.

sp.stage: Enter Lasso, with Syluan and a Nymph, a man Bugge, and a woman.
sp.p: 1 I pray my Lord, must not I weare this haire?

lg.l: I pray thee aske my Vsher; Come, dispatch,
The duke is readie: are you readie there?
2 See master Vsher; must he weare this haire?
Pray master Vsher, where must I come in?
2 Am not I well for a Bug, master Vsher?
What stirre is with these boyes here, God forgiue me,
If t'were not for the credite on't, I'de see
Your apish trash attire, ere I'de indure this.
1 But pray good master Vsher.
Hence ye Brats,
You stand vpon your tyre; but for your action
Which you must vse in singing of your songs,
Exceeding dexterously and full of life,
I hope youle then stand like a sort of blocks,
Without due motion of your hands, and heads,
And wresting your whole bodies to your words,
Looke too't, y'are best; and in; Go; All go in:

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Come in my masters; lets be out anon.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: What, are all furnish well?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: All well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: More lights then here, and let lowd musicke sound.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Sound Musicke.
sp.stage: Enter Vincentio, Strozzabare, Margaret, Corteza, and Cynanche bearing her traine. After her the duke whispering with Medice, Lasso with Bassiolo, &c.

lg.l: Aduaunce your selfe, faire Dutchesse to this Throne,
As we haue long since raisde you to our heart,
Better decorum neuer was beheld,
Then twixt this state and you: And as all eyes
Now fixt on your bright Graces thinke it fit,
So frame your fauour to continue it.
My Lord; but to obey your earnest will,
And not make serious scruple of a ioy,
I scarce durst haue presumde this minuts height.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Vsher, cause other musicke; begin your shew.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Sound Consort; warne the Pedant to be readie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, I thinke you'le see a prettie shew.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: I can expect no lesse in such a presence.

lg.l: Lo what attention and state beautie breedes,
Whose moning silence no shrill herauld needes.
Lords of high degree,
And Ladies of low courtesie,
I the Pedant here,
Whom some call schoolmaistere,
Because I can speake best,
Approch before the rest.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: A verie good reason.

lg.l: But there are others comming,
Without maske or mumming:
For they are not ashamed,
If need be, to be named,
Nor will they hide their faces,
In any place or places;
For though they seeme to come,
Loded with Rush, and Broome:
The Broomeman you must know,
Is seigneur Pogio,
Nephew, as shall appeare,
To my Lord Strozza here.
O Lord, I thanke you sir, you grace me much.
And to this noble dame,
Whome I with finger name.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: A plague of that fooles finger.

sp.speaker: Sar.

lg.l: And women will ensue,
Which I must tell you true,
No women are indeed,
But Pages made for need,
To fill vp womens places.
By vertue of their faces,
And other hidden graces.
A hall, a hall; whist, stil, be mum,
For now with siluer song they come.

sp.stage: Enter Pogio, Fungus, with the song Broome-maid, and Rush-maid. After which, Pogio.

lg.l: Heroes, and Heroines, of gallant straine,
Let not these Broomes, motes in your eies remaine,
For in the Moone, theres one beares with'red bushes:
But we (deare wights) do beare greene broomes, green rushes,
Where of these verdant herbals cleeped Broome,
Do pierce and enter euerie Ladies roome,
And to proue them high borne, and no base trash,
Water with which your phisnomies you wash,
Is but a Broome. And more truth to deliuer,
Grim Hercules swept a stable with a riuer,
The wind that sweepes fowle clowds out of the ayre,
And for you Ladies makes the Welken faire,
Is but a Broome: and O Dan Titan bright,
Most clearkly calld the Scauenger of night,
What art thou, but a verie broome of gold?
For all this world not to be cride nor sold;
Philosophy, that passion sweepes from thought,
Is the soules Broome, and by all braue wits sought,
Now if Philosophers but Broomemen are,
Each Broomeman then is a Philosopher.
And so we come (gracing your gratious Graces)
To sweepe Cares cobwebs from your cleanly faces.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Thanks good master Broomeman,

lg.l: For me Rushman then,
To make Rush ruffle in a verse of ten,
A Rush which now your heeles doe lie on here.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Crie mercie sir.

lg.l: Was whilome vsed for a pungent speare,
In that odde battaile, neuer fought but twice
(As Homer sings) betwixt the frogs and mice,
Rushes make True-loue know; Rushes make rings,
Your Rush maugre the beard of whiter springs:
And when with gentle, amorous, laysie lims,
Each Lord with his faire Ladie sweetly swims
On these coole Rushes; they may with these bables,
Cradles for children make; children for cradles,
And lest some Momus here might now crie push,
Saying our pageant is not woorth a Rush,
Bundles of Rushes, lo, we bring along,
To picke his teeth that bites them with his tongue.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: See, see, thats Lord Medice.

lg.l: Gods me, my Lord,
Haz hee pickt you out, picking of your teeth?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: What picke you out of that?

lg.l: Not such stale stuffe
As you picke from your teeth.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Leaue this warre with Rushes,
Good master pedant; pray forth with your shew.

lg.l: Lo thus farre then (braue duke) you see
Meere entertainement; Now our glee
Shall march forth in Moralitie:
And this queint Dutchesse here shall see
The fault of virgine Nicetie,
First wooed with Rurall courtesie,
disburthen them; praunce on this ground,
And make your exit with your Round.
Well haue they daunc'd as it is meet,
Both with their nimble heades and feet.
Now, as our country girls held off,
And rudely did their louers scoff;
Our Nymph likewise shall onely glaunce
By your faire eies, and looke askaunce
Vpon her female friend that wooes her.
Who is in plaine field forc'd to loose her.
And after them, to conclude all,
The purlue of our Pastorall.
A female bug, and eke her friend,
Shall onely come and sing, and end
This Lady and Dutchesse we conclude,
Faire Virgins must not be too rude:
For though the rurall wilde and antike,
Abusde their loues as they were frantike;
Yet take you in your Iuory clutches,
This noble Duke, and be his Dutches.
Thus thanking all for their tacete,
I void the roome, and cry valete.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Generally well, and pleasingly performed.

lg.l: Now I resigne this borrowed maiesty,
Which sate vnseemely on my worthlesse head,
With humble seruice to your Highnesse hands.
Well you became it Lady, and I know
All heere could wish it might be euer so.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Heeres one saies nay to that.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Plague on you, peace.

lg.l: Now let it please your Highnesse to accept
A homely banquet, to close these rude sports.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I thanke your Lordship much.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Bring lights, make place.
sp.stage: Enter Pogio in his cloke and broome-mans attire.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: How dee my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: O master broomeman, you did passing well.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: A you mad slaue you! you are a tickling Actor.

lg.l: I was not out like my Lord Medice.
How did you like me Aunt?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O rarely, rarely.

lg.l: O thou hast done a worke of memory,
And raisde our house vp higher by a story.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Friend, how conceit you my young mother heere?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Fitter for you my Lord, than for your father.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: No more of that sweete friend, those are bugs words.

div.head: ACTVS TERTII
SCAENA PRIMA.
div.stage: Medice after the song, whispers alone with his seruant.

lg.l: Thou art my trusty seruant and thou knowst,
I haue beene euer bountifull Lord to thee,
As still I will be: be thou thankfull then,
And doe me now a seruice of import.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Any my Lord in compasse of my life.

lg.l: To morrow then the Duke intends to hunt,
Where Strozza my despightfull enemie,
Will giue attendance busie in the chase,
Wherein (as if by chance, when others shoote
At the wilde Boare) do thou discharge at him,
And with an arrow, cleaue his canckerd heart.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will not faile my Lord.

lg.l: Be secret then.
And thou to me shalt be the dear'st of men.
Now Vanitie and Policie inrich me
With some ridiculous fortune on this Vsher.
Wheres Master Vsher?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Now I come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Besides, good sir, your shew did shew so well,

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Did it in deede my Lord?

lg.l: O sir, beleeue it;
Twas the best fashiond and well orderd thing
That euer eye beheld: and there withall,
The fit attendance by the seruants vsde,
The gentle guise in seruing euery guest,
In other entertainements; euery thing
About your house so sortfully disposde,
That euen as in a turne-spit calld a Iacke,
One vice assists another; the great wheeles
Turning but softly, make the lesse to whirre
About their businesse; euery different part
Concurring to one commendable end:
So, and in such conformance, with rare grace,
Were all things orderd in your good lordes house.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: The most fit simile that euer was.

lg.l: But shall I tell you plainely my conceit,
Touching the man that I thinke causde this order?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You note my simile.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Drawne from the turne-spit.

lg.l: I see you haue me,
Euen as in that queint engine you haue seene,
A little man in shreds stand at the winder,
And seemes to put all things in act about him,
Lifting and pulling with a mightie stirre,
Yet addes no force to it, nor nothing does:
So, (though your Lord be a braue Gentleman)
And seemes to do this busines,
He does nothing;
Some man about him was the festiuall robe,
That made him shew so glorious and diuine.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I cannot tell my Lord, yet I should know if any such there were.

lg.l: Should know quoth you;
I warrant you know: well, some there be
Shall haue the fortune to haue such rare men,
(Like braue beasts to their Armes) support their state,
When others of as high a worth and breede,
Are made the wastefull food of them they feede:
What state hath your Lord made you for your seruice?
He haz beene my good Lord, for I can spend
Some fifteene hundred crownes in lands a yeare,
Which I haue gotten since I seru'd him first.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: No more then fifteene hundred crownes a yeare?

lg.l: It is so much as makes me like my Lord,
Like a poore Gentleman.
Nay, tis prettie well:
But certainely my nature does esteeme
Nothing enough for vertue; and had I
The Duke my fathers meanes, all should be spent,
To keepe braue men about me: but good sir,
Accept this simple iewell at my hands,
Till I can worke perswasion of my friendship,
With worthier arguments.
No good my Lord,
I can by no meanes merite the free bounties
You haue bestowed besides.
Nay, be not strange,
But doe your selfe right, and be all one man
In all your actions, doe not thinke but some
Haue extraordinarie spirits like your selfe,
And wil not stand in their societie,
On birth and riches: but on worth and vertue,
With whom there is no nicenesse, nor respect
Of others common friendship; be he poore
Or basely borne, so he be rich in soule,
And noble in degrees of qualities,
He shall be my friend sooner then a King.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: To a most kingly iudgement in your lordship,

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Faith sir I know not, but tis my vaine humour.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O, tis an honour in a Nobleman.

lg.l: Y'aue some lords now so politike and prowd,
They skorne to giue good lookes to worthy men.
O fie vpon vm; by that light my lord,
I am but seruant to a Nobleman,
But if I would not skorne such puppet lords,
Would I weare breathlesse.
You sir? so you may,
For they will cogge so when they wish to vse men,
With, pray be couerd sir, I beseech you sit,
Whoe's there? waite of Master Vsher to the doore.
O, these be godly gudgeons: where's the deedes?
The perfect Nobleman?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O good my Lord.

lg.l: Away, away, ere I would flatter so,
I would eate rushes like lord Medici.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well, wel my Lord, would there were more such Princes.

lg.l: Alas, twere pitty sir, they would be gulld
Out of their very skinnes.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why how are you my lord?

lg.l: Who I, I care not:
If I be where I professe plaine loue,
T'will be their faults you know.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O t'were their shames.

lg.l: Well, take my iewell, you shall not be strange,
I loue not manie words.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: My lord, I thanke you, I am of few words too.

lg.l: Tis friendlie said,
You proue your selfe a friend, and I would haue you
Aduance your thoughts, and lay about for state,
Worthy your vertues: be the Mineon
Of some great King or Duke: theres Medici,
The Minion of my Father: O the Father!
What difference is there? but I cannot flatter
A word to wise men.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I perceiue your Lordship.

lg.l: Your Lordship? talke you now like a friend?
Is this plaine kindnesse?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Is it not my Lord?

lg.l: A palpable flattring figure for men common:
A my word I should thinke, if twere another,
He meant to gull mee.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why tis but your due.

lg.l: Tis but my due: if youle be still a stranger:
But as I wish to choose you for my friend,
As I intend when God shall call my father,
To doe I can tell what: but let that passe,
Thus tis not fit; let my friend be familiar,
Vse not me Lordship, nor yet call me Lord,
Nor my whole name Vincentio; but vince,
As they call Iacke or Will, tis now in vse,
Twixt men of no equallity or kindnesse.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I shall be quickely bold enough my Lord.

lg.l: Nay, see how still you vse that coy terme, Lord
What argues this, but that you shunne my friendship?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, pray say not so.

lg.l: Who should not say so?
Will you afford me now no name at all?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: What should I call you?

lg.l: Nay, then tis no matter.
But I told you Vince.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why then my sweete Vince.

lg.l: Whie so then; and yet still there is a fault,
In vsing these kind words, without kinde deedes:
Pray thee imbrace me too.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why then sweete Vince.

lg.l: Why now I thank you, sblood shall friends be strange?
Where there is plainenesse, there is euer truth:
And I will still be plaine since I am true:
Come let vs lie a little, I am wearie.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: And so am I, I sweare since yesterday.

lg.l: You may sir by my faith; and sirra, hark thee,
What lordship wouldst thou wish to haue ifaith,
When my old father dies?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Who I? alas.

lg.l: O not you, well sir, you shall haue none,
You are as coy a peece as your Lords daughter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Who, my mistris?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Indeede, is she your Mistris?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I faith sweet Vince, since she was three yeare old.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And are not wee too friends?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Who doubts of that?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And are not two friends one?

sp.speaker: Basis.
sp.p: Euen man and wife.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Then what to you she is, to me she should be.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why Vince, thou wouldst not haue her?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O not I: I doe not fancie any thing like you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay but I pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.p: You do not meane to marry her your self?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Not I by heauen.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Take heede now, do not gull me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: No by that candle.

lg.l: Then will I be plaine.
Thinke you she dotes not too much on my father?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O yes, no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you speake.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: You seely man you, she cannot abide him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Why sweete friend pardon me, alas I knew not.

lg.l: But I doe note you are in some things simple,
And wrong your selfe too much.
Thanke you good friend,
For your playne dealing, I doe meane so well.
But who saw euer summer mixt with winter?
There must be equall yeares where firme loue is.
Could we two loue so well so soddainely
Were we not some thing equaller in yeares.
Than he and shee are?
I cry ye mercy sir, I know we could not, but yet be not too bitter,
Considering loue is fearefull. And sweete friend,
I haue a letter t'intreate her kindnesse.
Which if you would conuay.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I, if I would sir?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Why fayth, deare friend, I would not die requitelesse.

lg.l: Would you not so sir?
By heauen a little thing would make me boxe you,
Which if you would convaie? why not I pray?
Which (friend) thou shalt conuaie.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Which friend, you shall then.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well friend, and I will then.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And vse some kinde perswasiue wordes for me?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: The best I sweare that my poore toung can forge.

lg.l: I, wel said, poore toung: O tis rich in meekenesle;
You are not knowne to speake well? You haue wonne
Direction of the Earle and all his house,
The fauour of his daughter, and all Dames
That euer I sawe, come within your sight,
With a poore tongue? A plague a your sweete lippes.
Well, we will doe our best: And faith my Uince,
She shall haue an vnweldie and dull soule,
If she be nothing moou'd with my poore tongue,
Call it no better; Be it what it will.
Well said ifaith; Now if I doe not thinke
Tis possible, besides her bare receipt
Of that my Letter, with thy friendly tongue.
To get an answere of it, neuer trust me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: An answer man? Sbloud make no doubt of that.

lg.l: By heauen I thinke so; now a plague of Nature,
That she giues all to some, and none to others.
How I endeare him to me! Come Vince, rise,
Next time I see her, I will giue her this:
Which when she sees, sheele thinke it wondrous strange
Loue should goe by descent, and make the sonne
Follow the father in his amorous steppes.
Shee needes must thinke it strange, that neuer yet saw
I durst speake to her, or had scarce hir sight.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well Vince, I sweare thou shalt both see and kisse her.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: Sweares my deere friend? by what?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Euen by our friendship.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O sacred oath! which, how long will you keepe?

lg.l: While there be bees in Hybla, or white swannes
In bright Meander; while the banks of Po
Shall beare braue lillies; or Italian dames
Be called the Bone robes of the world.
Tis elegantly said: and when I faile,
Let there be found in Hybla hiues no bees;
Let no swannes swimme in bright Meander streame,
Nor lillies spring vpon the banks of Po,
Nor let one fat Italian dame be found,
But leane and brawn-falne; I, and scarsly sound.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: It is enough, but lets imbrace with all.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: With all my hart.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So, now farewell sweet Vince.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Farewell my worthie friend, I thinke I haue him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I had forgot the parting phrase he taught me, I commend me t'ee sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.

lg.l: At your wisht seruice sir:
O fine friend, he had forgot the phrase:
How serious apish soules are in vaine forme:
Well, he is mine, and he being trusted most
With my deare ioue, may often worke our meeting,
And being thus ingagde, dare not reueale.

sp.stage: Enter Pogio in haste, Strozza following.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Horse, horse, horse, my lord, horse, your father is going a hunting.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: My Lord horse? you asse you d'ee call my Lord horse?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Nay, he speakes huddles still, lets slit his tongue.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Nay good vnkle now, sbloud, what captious, marchants you be; so the Duke tooke me vp euen now: my lord vnckle heere, and my old lord Lasso, by heauen y'are all too witty for me, I am the veriest foole on you all, Ile be sworne.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Therein thou art worth vs all, for thou knowst thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But your wisedom was in a pretty taking last night; was it not I pray?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p:
O, for taking my drink a little? faith my Lord, for that you shall haue the best sport presently with Madam Corteza,
that euer was; I haue made her so drunke, that she does nothing but kisse my Lord Medice.
See shee comes riding the Duke, shees passing well mounted, beleeue it.
sp.stage: Enter Alphonso, Corteza, Cynanche Bassiolo first, two women attendants, and hunts-men, Lasso.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Good wench forbeare.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: My Lord, you must put forth your selfe among Ladies, I warrant you haue much in you, if you would shew it; see, a cheeke a twentie; the bodie of a George, a good legge still; still a good calfe, and not slabby, nor hanging I warrant you; a brawne of a thumb here, and t'were a pulld partridge; Neece Meg, thou shalt haue the sweetest bedfellow on him, that euer call'd Ladie husband; trie him you shamefac'd bable you, trie him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good Madame be rulde.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: What a nice thing it is, my Lord, you must set foorth this gere, and kisse her; yfaith you must; get you together and be naughts awhile, get you together.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Now what a merrie harmlesse dame it is!

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: My Lord Medice, you are a right noble man, & wil do a woman right in a wrong matter and neede be; prav do you giue the duke ensample vpon me; you come a wooing to me now; I accept it.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: What meane you sister?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: Pray my Lord away; consider me as I am, a woman.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Lord, how I haue whittled her?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: You come a wooing to me now; pray thee Duke marke my Lord Medice; and do you marke me virgin; Stand you aside, my Lord, all, and you; giue place; now my Lord Medice, put case I be strange a little, yet you like a man put me to it. Come kisse me my Lord, be not ashamde.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Not I Madame, I come not a wooing to you.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Fie sister, y'are too blame; pray will you goe to your chamber

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: Dee thinke I am drunke?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: I thinke so truly.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: But are you sure I am drunke?

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Else I would not thinke so.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: But, I would be glad to be sure on't.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: I assure you then.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.p: Why then say nothing; & Ile begone God bwy lord, duke
Ile come againe anone.

lg.l: I hope your Grace will pardon her my liege,
For tis most strange; shees as discreete a dame
As any in these countries, and as sober,
But for this onely humour of the cup
Tis good my Lord sometimes:
Come, to our hunting; now tis time I thinke.
The verie best time of the day, my Lord.
Then my Lord, I will take my leaue till night,
Reseruing thanks for all my entertainment,
Till I returne; in meane time, louely dame,
Remember the high state you last presented, Vin. & St. haue all this while talked togither a prettie way.
And thinke it was not a mere festiuall shew,
But an essentiall type of that you are
In full consent of all my faculties
And harke you good my Lord.
See now, they whisper
Some priuate order, (I dare lay my life)
For a forc'd marriage t'wixt my loue and father,
I therefore must make sure: and noble friends,
Ile leaue you all, when I haue brought you forth,
And seene you in the chase; meane-while obserue
In all the time this solemne hunting lasts,
My father and his minion Medice,
And note, if you can gather any signe,
That they haue mist me, and suspect my being,
If which fall out, send home my Page before.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: I will not faile my Lord.
sp.stage: Medice whispers with I. Huntsman all this while.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Now take thy time.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: I warrant you my Lord, he shall not scape me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Now my deere Mistresse, till our sports intended end with my absence, I will take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.p: Bassiolo, attend you on my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Now will the sport beginne; I think my loue Will handle him, as well as I haue doone.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Madam, I take my leaue, and humblie thanke you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Welcome good madam; mayds wait on my Lady.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So mistris, this is fit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fit sir, why so?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why so? I haue most fortunate newes for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For me sir? I beseech you what are they?

lg.l: Merit and Fortune, for you both agree;
Merit what you haue, and haue what you merit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord with what Rhetorike you prepare your newes!

lg.l: I need not; for the plaine contents they beare
Vttred in any words, deserue their welcome,
And yet I hope the words will serue the turne.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, in a letter?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whence is it?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: From one that will not shame it with his name. And that is Lord Vincentio.

lg.l: King of heauen!
Is the man madde?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Mad Madam, why?

lg.l: O heauen, I muse a man of your importance,
Will offer to bring me a letter thus?
Why, why good Mistresse, are you hurt in that?
Your answer may be what you will your selfe.
I, but you should not doe it: Gods my life,
You shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, you must answer it.

lg.l: I answer it! are you the man I trusted?
And will betray me to a stranger thus?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Thats nothing, dame, all friends were strangers first.

lg.l: Now was there euer woman ouerseene so,
In a wise mans discretion?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Your braine is shallow, come, receiue this letter.

lg.l: How dare you say so? when you know so well
How much I am engaged to the duke?
The duke? a proper match: a graue olde gentman:
Haz beard at will; and would, in my conceyt,
Make a most excellent patterne, for a potter
To haue his picture stampt on a Iugge.
To keepe ale-knights in memorie of sobrietie.
Heere gentle madam, take it.
Take it sir?
Am I common taker of loue letters?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Common? why when receiu'd you one before?

lg.l: Come, tis no matter; I had thought your care
Of my bestowing, would not tempt me thus
To one I know not; but it is because
You know I dote so much on your direction.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: On my direction?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No sir, Not on yours.

lg.l: Well mistris, if you will take my aduice
At any time, then take this letter now.
Tis strange, I woonder the coy gentleman,
That seeing mee so oft, would neuer speake,
Is on the sodaine so far wrapt to write.
It shewd his iudgement, that he would not speake
Knowing with what a strict and iealous eie
He should be noted; holde, if you loue yourselfe;
Now will you take this letter? pray be rulde.
Come, you haue such another plaguie toung,
And yet yfayth I will not.
Lord of heauen,
What, did it burne your hands? holde, hold, I pray,
And let the words within it fire your heart.
I woonder how the deuill, he found you our
To be his spokesman,‚Äî O the duke would thanke you,
If he knew how you vrgde me for his sonne.
The duke? I haue fretted her,
Euen to the liuer, and had much adoe
To make her take it, but I knew t'was sure;
For he that cannot turne and winde a woman
Like silke about his finger, is no man,
Ile make her answer't too.
O here's good stuffe.
Hold, pray take it for your paines to bring it.
Ladie you erre in my reward a little,
Which must be a kind answere to this letter.
Nay then yfaith, t'were best you brought a Priest;
And then your client; and then keepe the doore.
God me I neuer knew so rude a man.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Wel, you shall answer; Ile fetch pen and paper.

lg.l: Poore Vsher, how wert thou wrought to this brake?
Men worke on one another for we women,
Nay each man on himselfe; and all in one
Say; No man is content that lies alone.
Here comes our gulled Squire.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Here Mistresse, write.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What should I write?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: An answer to this letter.

lg.l: Why sir, I see no cause of answer in it,
But if you needs will shew how much you rule me,
Sit downe; and answer it, as you please your selfe,
Here is your paper, lay it faire afore you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Lady, content, Ile be your Secretorie.

lg.l: I fit him in this taske; he thinkes his penne
The Shaft of Cupid, in an amorous letter.
Is heere no great worth of your answer say you?
Beleeue it, tis exceedingly well writ.
So much the more vnfit for me to answere,
And therefore let your Stile and it contend.
Well, you shall see I will not be farre short,
Although (indeede) I cannot write so well
When one is by, as when I am alone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O, a good Scribe must write, though twenty talke, and he talke to them too.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well, you shall see.

lg.l: A proper peece of Scribeship theres no doubt;
Some words, pickt out of Proclamations,
Or great mens Speeches; or well selling Pamphlets:
See how he rubbes his temples: I beleeue
His Muse lies in the backe-part of his braine,
Which thicke and grosse, is hard to be brought forward,
What? is it loath to come?
No, not a whit:
Pray hold your peace a little.
He sweates, with bringing on his heauie stile,
Ile plie him still, till he sweate all his wit out,
What man, not yet?
Swoons, yowle not extort it from a man,
How do you like the worde Endeare?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O fie vpon't.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, then I see your iudgement: what say you to condole?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O braue! I should make a sweete answer, if I should vse no words but of your admittance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well sir, write what you please.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Is modell a good word with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Put them togither I pray.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So I will I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: See, see, see, now it comes powring downe.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I hope youle take no exceptions to beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Out vpon't, that phrase is so runne out of breath in trifles, that we shall haue no beleefe at all in earnest shortly. Beleeue it tis a prettie feather; beleeue it a daintie Rush; beleeue it an excellent Cocks-combe.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So, so, so, your exceptions sort very collaterally.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Collaterally? theres a fine word now; wrest in that if you can by any meanes.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: I thought she would like the very worst of them all, how thinke you? do not I write, and heare, and talke too now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By my soule, if you can tell what you write now, you write verie readily.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: That you shall see straight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But do you not write that you speake now?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O yes, doe you not see how I write it? I can not write when any bodie is by me, I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Gods my life, stay man; youle make it too long.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, if I can not tell what belongs to the length of a Ladies deuice yfaith.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But I will not haue it so long.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: If I cannot fit you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O me; how it comes vpon him? pre thee be short.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Wel, now I haue done, & now I wil reade it; your Lordships motiue accommodating my thoughts, with the very model of my hearts mature consideration: it shall not be out of my Element to negotiate with you in this amorous duello; wherein I will condole with you, that our proiect cannot be fo collaterally made, as our endeared hearts may verie well seeme to insinuate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No more: no more; fie vpon this.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Fie vpon this? hees accurst that haz to doe with these vnsound women, of iudgement: if this be not good yfaith.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But tis so good, t'will not be thought to come from a womans braine.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Thats another matter

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, I will write my selfe.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: A Gods name Lady: and yet I will not loose this I warrant you; I know for what Ladie this will serue as fit; now we shall haue a sweete peece of inditement.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How spell you foolish?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: F , oo , l , i. sh; she will presume t'endite that cannot spel:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How spell you Vsher?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Sblood, you put not in those words togither, do you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, not togither.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: What is betwixt I pray?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Asse the.

lg.l: Asse the? betwixt foolish, and Vsher,
Gods my life, foolish Asse the Vsher?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay then you are so iealous of your wit: now reade all I haue written I pray.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: I am not so foolish as the Vsher would make me: O so foolish as the Vsher would make me? Wherein would I make you foolish?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why sir, in willing me to beleeue he lou'd me so wel, being so meere a stranger.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O, is't so? you may say so indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Cry mercie sir, and I will write so too, & yet my hand is so vile, Pray thee sit thee downe and write as I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: With all my heart Lady, what shall I write now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You shall write this sir, I am not so foolish to thinke you loue me, being so meere a stranger.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: So meere a stranger!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And yet I know, loue works strangely.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Loue workes strangely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And therefore take heed, by whom you speake for loue.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Speake for loue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For he may speake for himselfe.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: May speake for himselfe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not that I desire it,

sp.speaker: Bass
sp.p: Desire it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But if he do; you may speede, I confesse.

sp.speaker: Basse.
sp.p: Speede I confesse.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But let that passe, I do not loue to discourage any bodie.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Discourage any bodie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do you or he picke out what you can; & so farewell.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: And so fare well. Is this all?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I, and he may thanke your Syrens tongue that it is so much.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: A proper Letter if you marke it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well sir, though it be not so proper as the writer; yet tis as proper as the inditer; Euerie woman cannot be a gentleman Vsher; they that cannot go before, must come behind.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Well Ladie, this I will carrie instantly, I commend me tee Ladie.

lg.l: Pittifull Vsher, what a prettie sleight,
Goes to the working vp of euerie thing?
What sweet varietie serues a womans wit?
We make men sue to vs for that we wish.
Poore men; hold out a while; and do not sue,
And spite of Custome we will sue to you.

div.head: ACTVS QVARTI,
SCAENA PRIMA.
div.stage: Enter Pogio running in and knocking at Cynanches doore.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: O God, how wearie I am? Aunt, Madam. Cynanche, Aunt?

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: O God, Aunt: O God Aunt: O God.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: What bad newes brings this man? where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: O Aunt, my Vnkle, hees shot.

lg.l: Shot, ay me!
How is he shot?
Why with a forked shaft
As he was hunting, full in his left side.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O me accurst, where is hee? bring me, where?

sp.speaker: Pog.

lg.l: Comming with Doctor Beniuemus,
Ile leaue you, and goe tell my Lord Vincentio.

sp.stage: Enter Beniuemus with others, bringing in Strozza with an arrow in his side.

lg.l: See the sad sight, I dare not yeeld to griefe,
But force faind patience to recomfort him:
My Lord, what chance is this? how fares your lordship?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Wounded, and faint with anguish, let me rest.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: A chaire.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O Doctor, ist a deadly hurt?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I hope not Madam, though not free from danger.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Why plucke you not the arrow from his side?

lg.l: We cannot Lady, the forckt head so fast
Stickes in the bottome of his sollide ribbe.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: No meane then Doctor rests there to educe it?

lg.l: This onely, my good Lord, to giue your wound
A greater orifice, and in sunder break
The pierced ribbe; which being so neere the midriffe,
And opening to the region of the heart,
Will be exceeding dangerous to your life.
I will not see my bosome mangled so,
Nor sternely be anatomizde aliue,
Ile rather perish with it sticking still.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: O no; sweete doctor thinke vpon some help.

lg.l: I tolde you all that can be thought in Arte,
Which since your Lordship will not yeelde to vse,
Our last hope rests in Natures secret aide,
Whose power at length may happily expell it.
Must we attend at deaths abhorred doore,
The torturing delaies of slauish Nature?
My life is in mine owne powers to dissolue:
And why not then the paines that plague my life?
Rise furies, and this furie of my bane,
Assaile and conquer; what men madnesse calle
(That hath no eye to sense, but frees the foule,
Exempt of hope, and feare with instant fate)
Is manliest reason; manliest reason then,
Resolue and rid me of this brutish life,
Hasten the cowardly protracted cure
Of all diseases: King of Phisitians, death,
Ile dig thee from this Mine of miserie.
O hold my Lord, this is no christian part,
Nor yet skarce manly, when your mankinde foe,
Imperious death shall make your grones his trumpets
To summon resignation of lifes Fort,
To flie without resistance; you must force
A countermine of Fortitude, more deepe
Than this poore Mine of paines, to blow him vp,
And spight of him liue victor, though subdu'd:
Patience in torment, is a valure more
Than euer crownd Th' Alcmenean Conquerour.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Rage is the vent of torment, let me rise.

lg.l: Men doe but crie, that rage in miseries,
And scarcely beaten children, become cries:
Paines are like womens clamors, which the lesse
They find mens patience stirred, the more they cease.
Of this tis said, afflictions bring to God,
Because they make vs like him, drinking vp
Ioyes that deforme vs with the lusts of sense,
And turne our generall being into soule,
Whose actions simply formed and applied,
Draw all our bodies frailties from respect.
Away with this vnmedcinable balme
Of worded breath; for beare friends, let me rest,
I sweare I will be bands vnto my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: That will become your lordship best indeed.

lg.l: Ile breake away, and leape into the Sea.
Or from some Turret cast me hedlong downe,
To shiuer this fraile carkasse into dust.
O my deare Lord, what vnlike words are these,
To the late fruits of your religious Noblesse?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.p: Leaue me fond woman.

lg.l: Ile be hewne from hence
Before I leaue you; helpe me gentle Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Haue patience good my Lord.

lg.l: Then leade me in,
Cut off the timber of this cursed Shaft,
And let the fork'd pile canker to my heart.

sp.speaker: Cyn.
sp.p: Deare Lord, resolue on humble sufferance.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I will not heare thee, woman, be content.

sp.speaker: Cyn.

lg.l: O neuer shall my counsailes cease to knocke
At thy impatient eares, till they flie in
And salue with Christian patience, Pagan sinne.

sp.stage: Enter Vincentio with a letter in his hand, Bassiolo.

lg.l: This is her letter sir, you now shall see
How seely a thing tis in respect of mine,
And what a simple woman she haz prou'd,
To refuse mine for hers; I pray looke heere.
Soft sir, I know not, I being her sworn seruant,
If I may put vp these disgracefull words,
Giuen of my Mistris, without touch of honour.
Disgracefull words; I protest I speake not
To disgrace her, but to grace my selfe.
Nay then sir, if it be to grace your selfe,
I am content; but otherwise you know,
I was to take exceptions to a King.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Nay, y'are ith right for that; but reade I pray, if there be not more choice words in that letter, than in any three of Gueuaras golden epistles, I am a very asse. How thinke you Vince?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: By heauen no lesse sir, it is the best thing;
Gods what a beast am I.

lg.l: Is is no matter,
I can set it together againe.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Pardon me sir, I protest I was rauisht: but was it possible she should preferre hers before this?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: O sir, she cride fie vpon this.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Well, I must say nothing, loue is blind you know, and can finde no fault in his beloued.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Nay, thats most certaine.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Gee't me: Ile haue this letter.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: No good Vince, tis not worth it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ile ha't ifaith, heere's enough in it to serue for my letters as long as I liue; Ile keepe it to breede on as twere:
But I much wonder you could make her write.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Indeede there were some words belongd to that.

lg.l: How strong an influence works in well plac'd words,
And yet there must be a prepared loue,
To giue those words so mighty a command,
Or twere impossible they should moue so much:
And will you tell me true?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: In any thing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Does not this Lady loue you?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Loue me? why yes; I thinke she does not hate me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Nay but ifaith, does she not loue you dearely?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: No I protest.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Nor haue you neuer kist her?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Kist her, thats nothing.

lg.l: But you know my meaning:
Haue you not beene, as one would say, afore me?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Not I, I sweare.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O, y'are too true to tell.

lg.l: Nay be my troth, she haz, I must confesse,
Vsde me with good respect, and nobly still,
But for such matters.
Verie little more,
Would make him take her maidenhead vpon him:
Well friend, I rest yet in a little doubt,
This was not hers.
T'was by that light that shines,
And Ile goe fetch her to you to confirme it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O passing friend.

lg.l: But when she comes, in any case be bold,
And come vpon her with some pleasing thing,
To shew y'are pleasde: how euer she behaues her,
As for example; if she turne her backe,
Vse you that action you would doe before,
And court her thus; Lady, your backe part is as faire to me, as is your fore part.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: T'will be most pleasing.

lg.l: I, for if you loue
One part aboue another, tis a signe
You like not all alike, and the worst part
About your Mistris, you must thinke as faire,
As sweete, and daintie, as the very best,
So much, for so much, and considering too,
Each seuerall limbe and member in his kinde.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: As a man should.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: True, will you thinke of this?

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: I hope I shall.

lg.l: But if she chance to laugh,
You must not lose your countenance, but deuise
Some speech to shew you pleasde, euen being laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I, but what speech?

lg.l: Gods pretious man! do something of your selfe?
But Ile deuise a speech.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Inspire him folly.

lg.l: Or tis no matter, be but bold enough,
And laugh when she laughs, and it is enough:
Ile fetch her to you.
Now was there euer such a demilance,
To beare a man so cleare through thicke and thinne?
Or harke you sir, if she should steale a laughter
Vnder her fanne, thus you may say, sweete Lady,
If you will laugh and lie downe, I am pleasde.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And so I were by heauen; how know you that?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.p: Slid man, Ile hit your very thoughts in these things.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Fetch her sweete friend, Ile hit your words I warrant,

lg.l: Be bold then Vince, and presse her to it hard,
A shamefac'd man, is of all women barr'd.
How easly worthlesse men take worth vpon them,
And being ouer credulous of their owne worths,
Doe vnderprize as much the worth of others.
The foole is rich, and absurd riches thinks
All merit is rung out, where his purse chinks.
My Lord, with much intreaty heeres my Lady.
Nay Maddam, looke not backe: why Vince I say?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Vince? O monstrous ieast!

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: To her for shame.

lg.l: Lady, your backe part is as sweete to me
As all your fore part.
He miss'd alittle: he said her back part was sweet, when
He should haue said faire; but see, she laughs most fitly,
To bring in the tother: Vince, to her againe, she laughs.
Laugh you faire Dame?
If you will laugh and lie downe, I am pleasde.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What villanous stuffe is heere?

lg.l: Sweete Mistris, of meere grace imbolden now
The kind young Prince heere, it is onely loue
Vpon my protestation, that thus daunts
His most Heroicke spirit: so a while
Ile leaue you close together; Vince, I say‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O horrible hearing, does he call you Vince?

lg.l: O I, what else? and I made him imbrace me,
Knitting a most familiar league of friendship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But wherefore did you court me so absurdly?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Gods me, he taught me, I spake out of him.

lg.l: O fie vpon't, could you for pitty make him
Such a poore creature? twas abuse enough
To make him take on him such sawcie friendship;
And yet his place is great; for hees not onely
My fathers Vsher, but the worlds beside,
Because he goes before it all in folly.
Well, in these homely wiles, must our loues maske,
Since power denies him his apparant right,
But is there no meane to dissolue that power,
And to preuent all further wrong to vs,
Which it may worke, by forcing Mariage rites,
Betwixt me and the Duke?
No meane but one,
And that is closely to be maried first,
Which I perceiue not how we can performe:
For at my fathers comming backe from hunting,
I feare your father and himselfe resolue,
To barre my interest with his present nuptialls.
That shall they neuer doe; may not we now
Our contract make, and marie before heauen?
Are not the lawes of God and Nature, more
Than formall lawes of men? are outward rites,
More vertuous then the very substance is
Of holy nuptialls solemnizde within?
Or shall lawes made to curbe the common world,
That would not be contain'd in forme without them,
Hurt them that Are a law vnto themselues?
My princely loue, tis not a Priest shall let vs:
But since th'eternall acts of our pure soules,
Knit vs with God, the soule of all the world,
He shall be Priest to vs; and with such rites
As we can heere deuise, we will expresse,
And strongely ratifie our hearts true vowes,
Which no externall violence shall dissolue.
This is our onely meane t'enioy each other:
And, my deare life, I will deuise a forme
To execute the substance of our mindes,
In honor'd nuptialls. First then hide your face
With this your spotlesse white and virgin vaile:
Now this my skarfe Ile knit about your arme,
As you shall knit this other end on mine,
And as I knit it, heere I vow by Heauen,
By the most sweete imaginarie ioyes,
Of vntride nuptialls; by loues vshering fire,
Fore-melting beautie, and loues flame it selfe.
As this is soft and pliant to your arme
In a circumferent flexure, so will I
Be tender of your welfare and your will,
As of mine owne, as of my life and soule,
In all things, and for euer; onelie you
Shall haue this care in fulnesse, onely you
Of all dames shall be mine, and onely you
Ile court, commend and ioy in, till I die.
With like conceit only our arme this I tie,
And heere in sight of heauen, by it I sweare,
By my loue to you, which commands my life,
By the deare price of such a constant husband,
As you haue vowed to be: and by the ioy
I shall imbrace by all meanes to requite you:
Ile be as apt to gouerne as this silke,
As priuate as my face is to this vaile,
And as farre from offence, as this from blacknesse.
I will be courted of no man but you,
In, and for you shall be my ioyes and woes:
If you be sicke, I will be sicke, though well:
If you be well, I will be well, though sicke:
Your selfe alone my compleat world shall be,
Euen from this houre, to all eternity.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: It is inough, and binds as much as marriage.

lg.l: Ile see in what plight my poore louer stands,
Gods me! a beckons me to haue me gone,
It seemes hees entred into some good vaine:
Ile hence, loue cureth when he vents his paine.
Now my sweet life, we both remember well
What we haue vow'd shall all be kept entire
Maugre our fathers wraths, danger and death:
And to confirme this, shall we spend our breath?
Be well aduisde, for yet your choice shall be
In all things as before, as large and free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
